ygData.subject: Streaming media files

Subject: Streaming media files
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=164119653; y=7ulso6XWluCBNT03bHMtSL5bUXbk-oxA7uDXorG5KQHkBhZ1Ndk
X-Yahoo-Profile: ashenfelder

It's encouraging to read this dialog. We have been researching the streamin=
g-media capture problem at the Library of Congress and are eager to make pr=
ogress on automated capture.

There appear to be just a few non-HTTP protoc=
ols associated with most streaming media files, mainly RTSP and MMS. It is =
easy to capture those files via RTSP or MMS with commercial software such a=
s GetASF and CoCSoft Stream Down, but integrating the manually captured fil=
es with the archived Web sites is a problem. Having Heritrix get the stream=
ing media files along with the Web sites, and integrate it all, would solve=
 so much.

Another challenge is the increasingly common usage of JavaScript=
 to dynamically assemble the URL for the destination video or audio file. I=
n looking at the Web site for the Louisiana news channel WAFB (http://www.w=
afb.com/) it's clear, and frustrating, that we can't easily capture the pow=
erful video clips on the home page, in part because they are served up with=
 dynamically assembled JavaScript links.

In our crawl of US government Web=
 sites, we often encounter RTSP links within the metafiles, so the crawl st=
ops there. On a page like 
http://epw.senate.gov/epwmultimedia/epwmultimedi=
a.htm Heritrix will harvest the RAM file hyperlinked from "July 26, 2005" (=
http://epw.senate.gov/epwmultimedia/epw072605.ram) but the RAM file * a 1k =
file that points to the destination video file * contains this code: rtsp:/=
/video.webcastcenter.com/srs_g2/epw072605.rm. Because of the RTSP protocol,=
 the harvest stops there.

There are issues of redisplay in Wayback too. I =
hope this dialogue continues and grows. We can make slow progress.

Mike


=

Message: 1         
   Date: Thu,  8 Sep 2005 16:20:44 +0200
   From: nico=
las.baly@... 
Subject: Heritrix: crawls of stream content

Hi!

I'm doi=
ng my diploma work at European Archive.
My task is to implement a module fo=
r Heritrix crawler in order to crawl and
store AV contents (stream objects =
such as movies).

I'm new to this project and I'd like to know what was alr=
eady done in this. I've
heard that Heritrix works for certain movie's exten=
sions, but not for all.

My first task will be to point out all these unhan=
dled video formats and to find
out a way to archive them.

If anybody has e=
ven a beginning of solution, please let me know.

Thank you.

Nico

Message: =
2         
   Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 11:23:32 -0700
   From: Gordon Mohr <g=
ojomo@...>
Subject: Re: Heritrix: crawls of stream content

Heritri=
x currently only retrieves audiovisual content which is (1) served
via HTTP=
; and (2) of finite length.

We've created a page on the project wiki to ca=
pture ideas for doing
streaming media crawling; see:

  http://crawler.arch=
ive.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?StreamCrawling 

There's not much there yet; please=
 feel free to revise and add to that
page. (I'm sending you the wiki edit p=
assword separately.)

We'd first like to compile a list of real-world examp=
le streams that
institutions want to archive, but can't yet.

- Gordon @ IA=
